title: Research
text:
My PhD

I completed my PhD in Stem Cell Research at the University of Manchester where we were interested in making cartilage from stem cells to treat osteoarthritis.
Here I undertook a  study using large RNA-seq datasets we aimed to elucidate mechanisms at which stem cells become cartilage.


Post-doctoral Research Associate

After my PhD I took a position at the University of Edinburgh where I was tasked with making a stem cell model of the human thalamus to study the causes of Autism Spectrum Disorders.

title: DaiDipper
text:
Version 1 Version 2



DaiDipper V2 - Raspberry Pi & Python






DaiDipper V1 - Arduino



Motivation

Cancer incidence and mortality rates in Africa are increasing, in collaboration with Africa Cancer Trust (Registered Charity 1189665) we aimed to build a low-budget immunostaining machine to aid in cancer diagnostics; the DaiDipper.
Automated staining machines have been around for a while however they have a hefty price tag. We hope by making a cheap accessible ease of use automated staining machine we could aid in cancer diagnostics in poorly funded labs.

















The Properties of the DaiDipper:







Cheap



We aimed to have a total cost <£100






Open-access



All code and instructions to build on yourself will be published






Accessible



All components should be easily accessible






Ease of use



No expertise knowledge required



















Components

The first version of the DaiDipper was built using Arduino. It consists of;





Component
Price
Shop




UNO R3
£10
Banggood

£4
Banggood

£2

£15
Banggood


2004 LCD Smart Display Controller
£14
Amazon





For this beta type the total cost is only £45. The case is 3D printed using a model on  Thingiverse.

title: NeuroShiny
text:
Motivation

At the University of Edinburgh I was tasked with making a 3D stem cell model of the thalamus to aid in studying root causes of Autism Spectrum Disorders.
During my research I was constantly downloading, manipulating and making visualizations of different gene expression datasets in order to discover markers of the thalamus.
I thought to myself wouldn’t it be useful if there was one website where I could easily select a gene of interest and see how it’s expression changes in all these different datasets. I could see how it’s expression changes in different species, time-points and different cell models (3D vs. 2D) and thus; NeuroShiny was created.

About Me


Passionate about science and programming. Did a PhD in Stem Cell research where I first used R to unravel mechanisms by which stem cells can become cartilage. Have since become hooked on the possibilities of the R-verse.
When I’m not at my laptop, I’ll be paddle boarding with the dolphins off the coast of West Wales.
